question: Question_04_(vi)
statement:
Consider the function

\[f(x) = \frac{1}{4}x^{4} - 2x^{3} + \frac{9}{2}x^{2}.\]

vi) Provide a qualitatively accurate sketch of f(x). Make sure your
graph reflects the information above.
sols:
This function is a polynomial of degree 4, so the curve sketching
shouldn't offer too many difficulties. We have collected the following
information:

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  The function has no horizontal asymptotes (from
  \href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH102/December 2011/Question 4 (i)}{part
  i)} )
\item
  The function has a global minimum at \emph{x} = 0 (from
  \href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH102/December 2011/Question 4 (ii)}{part
  ii)} )
\item
  The function has two inflection points at \emph{x} = 1 and \emph{x} =
  3 (from
  \href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH102/December 2011/Question 4 (iii)}{part
  iii)} )
\item
  The function is decreasing up to its minimum and then increasing,
  except at \emph{x} = 3 where it has an inflexion point (from
  \href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH102/December 2011/Question 4 (iv)}{part
  iv)} )
\item
  The function is concave up all the way up to \emph{x} = 1, then
  concave down until \emph{x} = 3 and then concave up again (from
  \href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH102/December 2011/Question 4 (v)}{part
  v)} )
\end{itemize}

To get a better idea of what to sketch, we quickly compute the second
coordinates of the three points of interests:

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  Global minimum at (0,0)
\item
  Inflection points at (1, 11/4) and (3, 27/4)
\end{itemize}

This allows us to sketch the graph of this function. As we saw above,
this function is always positive, reaches a global minimum at the point
(0,0) and has two inflection points. This should give you a picture that
looks like:

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{MER_MATH102_Dec_2011_Q4vi.png}
\caption{MER MATH102 Dec 2011 Q4vi.png}
\end{figure}
hints:
The previous questions have given you all the information you need to be
able to transfer all that algebraic information into something geometric
(the sketch of the graph).

Ask yourself:

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  What does an asymptote (vertical or horizontal) look like?
\item
  What does a local maximum or minimum look like?
\item
  What about an inflexion point?
\item
  What does it look like when the function is increasing/decreasing?
\item
  What does it look like when the function is concave up/concave down?
\end{itemize}

Whatever you sketch, check whether your drawing matches the information
you collected.
